archetypes.label: The Forgewalker
archetypes.description: You are strongest in concept, but need to strengthen your foundational tools and systems (Hardware & Software).

archetypes.label: The Pathfinder
archetypes.description: You can navigate physical space, but need to learn to travel safely and connect online (Internet & Email).

archetypes.label: The Wordsmith
archetypes.description: Your focus is on clear communication. You are ready to craft professional documents and job stories (Word & Job Hunting).

archetypes.label: The Chartweaver
archetypes.description: You are ready to shape raw data into powerful insights and predictions (Excel).

archetypes.label: The Signalkeeper
archetypes.description: You hold the room. You are ready to master calm, clear communication in virtual spaces (Zoom & PowerPoint).

archetypes.label: The Makerbound
archetypes.description: Your imagination is ready to bring digital ideas into the physical world (3D Printing).

archetypes.label: The Scribe of Clouds
archetypes.description: You thrive in shared spaces. You are ready to collaborate instantly in the shared commons (Google Docs & Android/Chrome OS).

archetypes.label: The Asker of Why
archetypes.description: You are prepared to question, test, and tune the next generation of digital assistance (AI Series).

questions.question: What is the fundamental definition of a computer?

choices.text: An electronic device used exclusively for accessing the internet
An electronic device that manipulates, stores, retrieves, and processes data
A machine with a keyboard and mouse for typing documents
A device that only runs programs made by Microsoft or Google

questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! A computer’s core functions are to handle information by storing, retrieving, processing, and manipulating data.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Not quite. The broader definition is about data processing, not one task like browsing or typing.

questions.question: What are the four main, separate components of a standard desktop computer?

choices.text: Screen, CPU, Hard Drive, Power Button

questions.feedbackCorrect: Right! The four core components are monitor, system unit/tower, keyboard, and mouse.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Accessories and internal parts don’t count as the main external components.

questions.question: When entering personal information online, what is the key indicator of a secure website?

choices.text: The address bar displays a lock symbol and “https”
The website has a professional design and no ads

questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! The lock symbol and the ‘s’ in https indicate a secure, encrypted connection.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Domain endings, pop-up blockers, or design quality don’t guarantee security.

questions.question: What is the primary function of an Applicant Tracking System (ATS) in the hiring process?

choices.text: To schedule interviews with qualified candidates
To help employers filter applicants using keyword matching
To conduct automated video interviews with applicants
To write job descriptions for new roles

questions.feedbackCorrect: Exactly! An ATS screens resumes by scanning for keywords from the job description.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Scheduling/interviews can exist but are secondary. Writing job descriptions is HR’s job.

questions.question: In 1997, which IBM computer beat Garry Kasparov at chess?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! IBM’s Deep Blue beat Garry Kasparov in 1997.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Watson = Jeopardy!, Skynet = fictional, Analytical Engine = a design never built.

questions.question: Which of the following is an input device?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! A keyboard sends data into the computer.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Monitors, printers, and projectors are output devices.

questions.question: Which of the following is an output device?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Exactly! A monitor displays information.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Mouse, scanner, and microphone are input devices.

questions.question: Which of these storage devices is the fastest for accessing data?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! SSDs are much faster than HDDs or optical media.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: HDDs, flash drives, and CDs are slower than SSDs.

questions.question: Which of these best describes an operating system (OS)?

choices.text: A physical part of the computer
A program that manages hardware and software

questions.feedbackCorrect: Right! The OS is the bridge between hardware and applications.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: It isn’t hardware, storage, or malware—it's system software.

questions.question: You plug in a new mouse, and it works immediately. Which feature makes this possible?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! Plug and Play allows devices to be recognized without manual setup.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options don’t explain instant device recognition.

questions.question: Which of these is an example of cloud storage?

choices.text: Saving a file to your desktop
Uploading a file to Google Drive
Copying a file to a USB stick
Burning a file to a CD

questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Cloud storage means saving files on remote servers accessed via the internet.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Desktop, USB, and CDs are local storage methods.

questions.question: You’re working on a shared computer at the library. Where should you save your resume so you can access it later at home?

choices.text: On a USB drive or cloud storage

questions.feedbackCorrect: Exactly! Saving to a portable or cloud location ensures you can access it later.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Library desktops and printer queues are temporary and won’t be available once you leave.

questions.question: Which task requires both hardware and software working together?

choices.text: Typing on a keyboard to write a document
Storing a book on a shelf

questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! The keyboard (hardware) sends input, and the word processor (software) interprets it.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Only option A combines both.

questions.question: Which two companies developed Copilot and Gemini, respectively?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! Copilot was developed by Microsoft, and Gemini was developed by Google.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other pairings are incorrect.

questions.question: What is the most common, biodegradable thermoplastic for 3D printing?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! PLA is beginner-friendly and widely used.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: ABS, PETG, and Resin are more advanced or specialized.

questions.question: What does the STAR method help a job seeker do?

choices.text: Tell a compelling story in interviews
Identify keywords in a job description

questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! STAR (Situation, Task, Action, Result) structures behavioral answers.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options are unrelated to STAR.

questions.question: In 3D printing, what does a slicer do?

choices.text: Break the model into printable layers

questions.feedbackCorrect: Exactly! A slicer prepares the model for printing.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Modeling is CAD; cleaning is post-processing; calibration is setup.

questions.question: Gemini’s strength compared to Copilot is:
questions.feedbackCorrect: Correct! Gemini is strong in multimodal input and integrates with Google Workspace.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options are not Gemini’s strengths.

questions.question: What’s the safest first step when a bank email looks suspicious?

choices.text: Click the link and log in
Verify the sender and contact your bank through official channels
Forward the email to your contacts

questions.feedbackCorrect: Exactly! Always verify through official channels before taking action.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Clicking exposes credentials; deleting prevents review; forwarding spreads risk.

questions.question: Which task fits cloud collaboration tools like Google Docs or Microsoft 365?

choices.text: Co-authoring a report with teammates in real time

questions.feedbackCorrect: Cloud tools are designed for real-time, multi-user collaboration.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other tasks are individual or local.

questions.question: Best way to practice STAR before interviews?

choices.text: Write out past experiences and rehearse them with STAR

questions.feedbackCorrect: Practicing real experiences ensures your answers are structured and memorable.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: STAR needs all four parts: Situation, Task, Action, Result.

questions.question: Which shows responsible AI use at work?

choices.text: Paste AI text directly into a report
Draft with AI, then edit for accuracy
Ask AI to generate confidential client data

questions.feedbackCorrect: Responsible AI use means reviewing, editing, and ensuring accuracy before sharing.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options are careless or unethical.

questions.question: Why does infill percentage matter?

choices.text: It affects strength, weight, and material use

questions.feedbackCorrect: Infill balances durability with efficiency.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Color, nozzle size, and adhesion are unrelated to infill.

questions.question: Which scenario integrates AI and 3D printing?

choices.text: Use AI to generate a 3D model and print it

questions.feedbackCorrect: AI accelerates design while 3D printing brings it into the physical world.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Only option A showcases true workflow integration.

questions.question: Effective prompts should include:
questions.feedbackCorrect: Goal (what you want), Context (situation), Source (data/examples), Expectation (desired output).
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Other structures don’t define prompt engineering.

questions.question: Primary area to check when troubleshooting 3D print issues:
questions.feedbackCorrect: A strong first layer prevents warping and failed prints.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Cosmetics and brand don’t determine print success.

questions.question: What does probe Z offset set?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Nozzle-to-bed distance at zero height ensures proper first layer thickness.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Leveling, temperature, and speed are separate settings.

questions.question: Best use of AI to tailor a resume bullet for 'collaboration':

choices.text: Provide the bullet and keyword; ask AI to rewrite naturally

questions.feedbackCorrect: Give AI the original sentence and the target keyword to create a more targeted bullet.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Defining, searching, or deleting doesn’t tailor the resume.

questions.question: Next step before printing an AI-generated 3D model:

choices.text: Upload the design directly to the printer
Run the design through a slicer to generate printer instructions
Save the design as a Word document

questions.feedbackCorrect: All models must be sliced into layers for the printer.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Printers can’t read raw models; Word docs aren’t valid 3D files.

questions.question: Which demonstrates critical thinking with AI for research?

choices.text: Ask AI for multiple perspectives and cross-check sources

questions.feedbackCorrect: Verify and compare information; don’t rely blindly on AI.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options show over-reliance without judgment.

questions.question: AI can help a failing 3D print by:

choices.text: Analyzing the model file for errors and suggesting repairs

questions.feedbackCorrect: AI tools can scan and repair STL files to ensure printability.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: AI can’t physically fix hardware.

questions.question: Best integration of AI prompting with workplace email:

choices.text: Generate a generic email without context
Provide goal, audience, and tone before drafting
Translate an email into emojis only

questions.feedbackCorrect: Supplying context and expectations improves accuracy and professionalism.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options are careless or ineffective.

questions.question: Which synthesis ties AI, online safety, and 3D printing together?

choices.text: AI model + slicing + trusted, secure software downloads
Print a model without checking filament type
Ask AI to explain 3D printing history
Use a 3D printer only for decorative objects

questions.feedbackCorrect: This example connects AI design, 3D workflow, and online safety practices.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Only option A shows true cross-domain synthesis.

questions.question: In Excel, which formula adds values in A1 through A10?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Yes! =SUM(A1:A10) adds all the numbers in that range.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Other options are invalid or count entries, not sums.

questions.question: During a Zoom meeting, what should you do if you are not speaking?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Muting prevents background noise from disrupting the meeting.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Camera and screen sharing are optional, but muting is key etiquette.

questions.question: On an Android phone, where do you go to install new apps?
questions.feedbackCorrect: The Play Store is the official app marketplace for Android.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options don’t install apps.

questions.question: Which view in PowerPoint is best for rearranging the order of slides?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Slide Sorter shows all slides as thumbnails for easy reordering.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: Other views focus on editing or presenting.

questions.question: In Google Docs, how can you share a document so others can edit it?
questions.feedbackCorrect: Sharing with ‘Editor’ access allows others to make changes.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options don’t enable collaboration.

questions.question: Why is the first layer of a 3D print so important?

choices.text: It ensures adhesion and stability for the rest of the print

questions.feedbackCorrect: A strong first layer prevents warping and failed prints.
questions.feedbackIncorrect: The other options are unrelated to first-layer adhesion.
